name: WASP-18
scenarioDescription:
The WASP-18 Exoplanetary System


Overview

WASP-18 is a star with 1.22 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.23 times its radius. It is located 404.17 light years away from the solar system.

WASP-18 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the WASP-18 system


WASP-18 b

WASP-18 b was discovered by the SuperWASP observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.02 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of WASP-18 b is 3316.59372 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, WASP-18 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


WASP-18 c

WASP-18 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit timing variations method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of WASP-18 c is 55.23024 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, WASP-18 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system WASP-18, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by SuperWASP.
